title-group.article-title: Description of Aporcella minor sp. n. (Dorylaimida: Aporcelaimidae) from Iran, with an updated taxonomy of the genus
title-group.alt-title: Description of Aporcella minor sp. n. (Dorylaimida: Aporcelaimidae) from Iran, with an updated taxonomy of the genus

abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: A new species belonging to the genus Aporcella, collected in cultivated soils of East Azarbaijan province, Iran, is described and illustrated. The new species is characterised by its 1.08 (1.05-1.15) mm long body, two-layered cuticle, lip region offset by constriction and 12 (11-13) μm broad, odontostyle 13.0 (12.5-14.0) μm long or nearly equal to lip region diam., neck 310 (293-325) μm long, pharyngeal expansion 137 (128-144) μm long, occupying 43-45% of the total neck length, female genital system didelphic-amphidelphic, uterus simple, 34-48 μm long, vulva transverse (V = 59 (58-61)), tail conical with finely rounded terminus (30 (29-33) μm long, c = 34 (33-36), c′ = 1.5 (1.4-1.6)), and male absent. Molecular analyses, using Bayesian inference based on partial LSU sequences, confirm the monophyly of Aporcella as well as its clustering with other dorylaimid taxa characterised by the absence of pars refringens vaginae. The taxonomy of the genus is updated, with an emended diagnosis, list of species, key to their identification, and a compendium of the main morphometrics of species/populations described since the last available revision.

body.p: This is the third contribution devoted to characterising the members of the Iranian fauna belonging to Aporcella Andrássy, 2002. In two previous papers, the authors (Naghavi et al., 2019, 2020) provided descriptions and molecular data of two new species (A. malekimilanii Naghavi, Niknam, Vazifeh & Peña-Santiago, 2019 and A. talebii Naghavi, Niknam, Vazifeh & Peña-Santiago, 2020) as well as two described forms, namely A. vitrinus (Thorne & Swanger, 1936) Álvarez-Ortega, Subbotin & Peña-Santiago, 2013 and A. simplex (Thorne & Swanger, 1936) Álvarez-Ortega, Subbotin & Peña-Santiago, 2013.

A general nematode survey, conducted in 2016-2017 to study the dorylaimid fauna of the East Azarbaijan province in northwest Iran, yielded additional material of Aporcella. Its study revealed a population representing a third previously unknown Iranian species of the genus, whose characterisation is the main aim of this work.

After the new concept proposed for Aporcella by Álvarez-Ortega et al. (2013), several papers (Andrássy, 2012; Álvarez-Ortega & Peña-Santiago, 2013a, b, 2016; Naghavi et al., 2019, 2020) dealing with new species and/or populations of the genus have appeared. As a result, a revision of the taxonomy is advisable, this being the second objective of the present contribution.

sec.title: Nematode collection and extraction
sec.p: Several soil samples were collected from depths ranging from 5 to 30 cm in the active plant root zone in East Azarbaijan province, northwest Iran, during 2016-2017 and processed at the Nematology Laboratory, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran. Nematodes were extracted from soil using a tray method (Whitehead & Hemming, 1965) and subsequently killed, fixed and transferred to anhydrous glycerin according to De Grisse (1969). Morphometric data were made by using a drawing tube attached to an Olympus BX41 light microscope. Photographs were taken using DP50 digital camera connected to the microscope. Raw photographs were edited using Adobe® Photoshop® CS. Drawings were made by using CorelDRAW®, software version 12.

sec.title: Molecular identification
sec.p: For the molecular phylogenetic studies, two females were selected, studied individually on temporary slides, transferred to a small drop of distilled water or worm lysis buffer on a clean slide and crushed by a sterilised scalpel. The suspension was transferred to an Eppendorf tube containing 25.65 μl ddH2O, 2.85 μl 10× PCR buffer and 1.5 μl proteinase K (600 μg ml−1) (Promega). DNA samples were stored at −20°C until used as a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) template. The primers used for amplification of the D2-D3 expansion domains of the LSU rDNA were the forward D2A (5′-ACAAGTACCGTGAGGGAAAGTTG-3′) and the reverse D3B (5′ TCGGAAGGAACCAGCTACTA-3′) (Nunn, 1992). The 25 μl PCR reaction mixture was composed of 10 μl ddH2O, 12.5 μl PCR master mix (Ampilliqon), 0.75 μl of each forward and reverse primers and 1 μl of DNA template. The process was done using a BIO RAD Thermocycler Machine in accordance with Archidona-Yuste et al. (2016). The thermal cycling program for amplification was as follows: denaturation at 94°C for 2 min, 35 cycles of denaturation at 94°C for 30 s, annealing of primers at 55°C for 45 s and extension at 72°C for 3 min followed by a final elongation step at 72°C for 10 min. The PCR products were purified and sequenced in an Applied Biosystems® 3730/3730xl DNA Analyzer in South Korea. The newly generated sequences were deposited in the GenBank database under the accession number presented in the phylogenetic tree.

sec.title: Phylogenetic analyses
sec.p: The newly obtained sequences were aligned using MEGA6 (Tamura et al., 2013) and compared with those of other Aporcella species available in GenBank using the Nblast homology search program. Out-group taxa for dataset were chosen according to Álvarez-Ortega & Peña-Santiago (2016) and Peña-Santiago & Varela (2017). The appropriate model of base substitution was selected using MrModeltest 2.3 (Nylander, 2004) with the Akaike-supported model in conjunction with PAUP* v4.0b10 (Swofford, 2003). The sequence dataset was analysed with Bayesian inference algorithm implemented in MrBayes 3.1.2 (Ronquist & Huelsenbeck, 2003) under the general time-reversible model, with invariable sites and a gamma-shaped distribution (SYM + I + G), was selected and used in the phylogenetic analyses. The Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method within a BI analysis was used to estimate the posterior probabilities of the phylogenetic trees using the 50% majority rule. After discarding burn-in samples and evaluating convergence, the remaining samples were retained for further analyses. Bayesian posterior probability (BPP) were given on appropriate clades. The tree was visualised using the program Figtree 1.4.3 v.

caption.p: Aporcella minor sp. n. (female). A: Neck region; B: Anterior end; C: Entire body; D: Amphidial pouch; E: Anterior genital branch; F: Posterior end; G: Lateral chord.

Aporcella minor sp. n. (female, LM). A: Anterior end; B: Vagina; C: Pharyngeal expansion and pharyngo-intestinal junction; D: Amphidial pouch; E: Posterior genital branch; F: Posterior end; G: Entire body; H: Lateral chord. (Scale bars: A-F, H = 10 μm; G = 37 μm.).
Morphometrics of Aporcella minor sp. n. All measurements are in μm, except for L in mm, and in the form: mean ± s.d. (range).

sec.title: Material examined
sec.p: Eight females from one location; in general, in good state of preservation.

sec.title: Female
sec.p: Moderately slender to slender (a = 27-32) nematodes of medium size, 1.05-1.15 mm long. Body cylindrical, visibly tapering towards both ends, but more so towards posterior extremity as tail is conical. Habitus slightly curved ventrad after fixation, to an open C-shape. Cuticle two-layered, 1.5-2 μm thick at anterior region and along most of body and 3.0-3.5 μm on tail, outer layer thin, with constant thickness throughout body and bearing fine transverse striation, inner layer thicker than outer one. Cervical lacunae absent. Lateral chord 7-10 μm broad or occupying 17-24% of mid-body diam., bearing glandular bodies throughout body: 9-11 in pharyngeal region, 12-13 from pharynx base to vulva, 16-18 from vulva to anus, and 1 in caudal region. Body pores, if present, obscure. Lip region offset by constriction, 2.3-3.1 times as broad as high and 31-35% of body diam. at neck base, with slightly angular and separate lips, and weakly protruding labial and cephalic papillae. Amphid fovea funnel-shaped, its aperture 6.5-8 μm or 35-48% of lip region diam. Cheilostom a truncate cone, lacking any differentiation. Odontostyle typical of genus, comparatively short and robust, nearly equal (1.0-1.1 times) to lip region diam., and 1.0-1.3% of body length; aperture 8-9.5 μm long or occupying up to two-thirds (53-64%) its length. Guiding ring simple and somewhat plicate, located at 0.4-0.6 of lip region diam. from anterior end. Odontophore rod-like, 1.2-1.6 times odontostyle length long. Pharynx entirely muscular, gradually enlarging into basal expansion occupying 43-45% of total neck length, gland nuclei located as follows: DN = 62-67, S1N1 = 72-76, S1N2 = 76-84, S2N = 86-94. Nerve ring located at 108-113 μm from anterior end. Cardia rounded, conoid, 9-10 × 7-8 μm. Genital system didelphic-amphidelphic, both branches well and equally developed, anterior 163-205 μm long or 14-19% of total body length, posterior 168-196 μm long or 15-18% of total body length. Ovaries reflexed, variably developed, anterior 44-66 μm, posterior 55-66 μm long, with oocytes arranged first in two or more rows, then in a single row. Oviduct consisting of slender part and developed pars dilatata with distinct lumen, joining ovary subterminally. Oviduct-uterus junction marked by a distinct sphincter. Uterus a simple tube-like structure 34-48 μm long or 0.8-1.3 corresponding body diam. Vagina extending inwards for 14-18 μm or up to one-half (40-50%) of body diam., with pars proximalis 9-12 × 10-11 μm and surrounded by a weak musculature, pars refringens vaginae absent, and pars distalis 2.5-5 μm long. Vulva a transverse slit. Prerectum 1.8-3.1, rectum 0.8-1.4 anal body diam. long. Tail conical with finely rounded terminus, ventrally straight, dorsally convex with a very weak (occasionally nearly inconspicuous) dorsal concavity at tip, inner core not reaching tail tip due to a short hyaline portion occupying about one-fifth of total tail length, two pairs of caudal pores at middle of tail, one pair subdorsal, one sublateral.

sec.title: Male
sec.p: Unknown, and females not containing sperm cells in their genital tracts.

sec.title: Type locality and habitat
sec.p: The new species was collected in Iran, East Azarbaijan province, Sufiyan, Roodghat area, Mazraeh village (GPS coordinates: 38°15′49″ N, 46°09′18″ E, altitude 1542 m a.s.l.), from the rhizosphere of wheat (Triticum aestivum L.).

sec.title: Type material
sec.p: Female holotype and five female paratypes deposited at the Nematode Collection of the Department of Plant Protection, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran. Two female paratypes deposited with the Nematode Collection of the University of Jaén, Spain.

sec.title: Diagnosis and relationships
sec.p: The new species is characterised by its 1.08 (1.05-1.15) mm long body, two-layered cuticle, lip region 12 (11-13) μm broad and offset by a constriction, odontostyle 13 (12.5-14.0) μm long or nearly equal to lip region diam., neck 310 (293-325) μm long, pharyngeal expansion 137 (128-144) μm long and occupying 43-45% of the total neck length, female genital system didelphic-amphidelphic, uterus simple and 34-48 μm long, vulva transverse (V = 59 (58-61)), tail conical with finely rounded terminus, (30 (29-33) μm, c = 34 (33-36), c′ = 1.5 (1.4-1.6)), and male absent.

Within Aporcella, and in having short odontostyle (up to 17 μm long) and comparatively stout body (a ⩽ 37), A. minor sp. n. belongs to a group of very similar species, including A. adriaani (Botha & Heyns, 1990) Álvarez-Ortega, Subbotin & Peña-Santiago, 2013, A. capitulum (Shahina, Musarrat & Siddiqi, 2005) Álvarez-Ortega, Subbotin & Peña-Santiago, 2013, A. charidemiensis Álvarez-Ortega & Peña-Santiago, 2016, A. talebii and A. vitrinus. It can, however, be easily distinguished from all by its smaller general size (L = 1.08 (1.05-1.15) vs > 1.20 mm, neck 310 (293-325) vs more than 320 μm long) and comparatively longer female tail (c′ = 1.5 (1.4-1.6) vs up to 1.4). It differs from A. adriaani, a species only known from South Africa, by its shorter odontostyle (13.0 (12.5-14.0) vs 15 (14-16) μm), more posterior vulva (V = 59 (58-61) vs = 55 (53-57)), and female tail shape (conical vs rounded to convex conoid); from A. capitulum, from Pakistan, by its narrower lip region (12 (11-13) vs 14-20 μm), and absence of males (vs as frequent as females); from A. charidemiensis, from Spain, by its narrower lip region (12 (11-13) vs 16.3 (16-17) μm), female tail shape (conical vs rounded to convex conoid), and the absence (vs presence) of males; from A. talebii, another Iranian species, by its narrower lip region (12 (11-13) vs 15-17 μm, two populations), shorter odontostyle (13.0 (12.5-14.0) vs 14-18 μm), and somewhat more posterior vulva (V = 59 (58-61) vs = 52-59); and from A. vitrinus by its more posterior vulva (V = 59 (58-61) vs = 48-56, several populations).

caption.p: Consensus 50% majority rule Bayesian phylogenetic tree of Aporcella minor sp. n. based on 28S rDNA D2-D3 sequences under the SYM + I + G model. Posterior probabilities more than 50% are given for appropriate clades. The newly obtained sequence is in bold.

sec.p: As derived from the molecular analyses, using Bayesian Inference based on partial LSU sequences, the evolutionary relationships of A. minor sp. n. are shown in Figure 3. The new species forms a highly supported (93%) clade with other Aporcella sequences, including A. charidemiensis from Spain and other sequences of several Iranian species/ populations. Aporcella simplex sequences are also clustered with the remaining Aporcella sequences in a larger clade, but with lower support (78%). Thus, the general topology of the inferred phylogeny in this study is similar to those provided in previous studies (Álvarez-Ortega et al., 2013; Álvarez-Ortega & Peña-Santiago, 2016; Naghavi et al., 2019, 2020), supporting the monophyly of the genus. In addition, the results obtained also confirm a close relationship between Aporcella and other dorylaimid genera that lack a distinct pars refringens vaginae, namely members of the Qudsianematidae Jairajpuri, 1965 and Tylencholaimidae Filipjev, 1934. Nevertheless, the evolutionary relationships within this clade are still not satisfactorily resolved, so that further morphological and molecular studies, using additional DNA markers, such as internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions of rDNA, and non-genomic markers, such as mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit I gene (COI mtDNA), are necessary to elucidate this matter.

The new species also resembles some species belonging to other genera that lack pars refringens vaginae, a complex group with intricate taxonomy (see below). For instance, it is similar to Metaporcelaimus cylindricus Ahmad, 1995 in the measurements of the lip region and odontostyle (Ahmad, 1995), and is very similar to Moshajia idiophora Siddiqi, 1982 in its general appearance and morphometrics (Siddiqi, 1982 and see recent data by Imran et al., 2019). Nevertheless, it can be easily separated from M. cylindricus by its smaller general female size (L = 1.08 (1.05-1.15) vs 1.63-1.68) and short uterus (34-48 vs 90-115 μm) among other relevant traits. It can also be distinguished by the nature of its cuticle (dorylaimoid vs tylencholaimoid), more posterior vulva (V = 59-61 vs very occasionally exceeding 57, several populations), and different morphology of the tail inner core (not reaching the tail tip as there is a hyaline portion occupying one-fifth of total tail length vs nearly always reaching the tail tip with no hyaline portion according to Fig. 2M-Q in Imran et al., 2019), the latter representing a small yet remarkable difference.

sec.title: Molecular characterisation
sec.p: After sequencing and editing, a 705 bp long sequence of the D2-D3 region of 28S rDNA (GenBank accession MT079124) was obtained for the new species. The evolutionary relationships of the new species are presented in Figure 3.

sec.title: Taxonomy
sec.p: As mentioned in the introductory section, since the last revision of the genus by Álvarez-Ortega et al. (2013), several relevant novelties affecting the taxonomy of the genus have appeared, either through descriptions of new species/populations (Andrássy, 2012; Álvarez-Ortega & Peña-Santiago, 2013a, 2016; Naghavi et al., 2019, 2020) or transference of species from other genera (Andrássy, 2012; Álvarez-Ortega & Peña-Santiago, 2013b). Thus, an updated diagnosis and relationships, list of species and key to their identification are provided hereunder. Table 2 presents a compendium of the main morphometrics corresponding to those species/populations described since 2013.

caption.p: Main morphometrics and distribution data of recently (since 2013) described populations and/or transferred species of the genus Aporcella Andrássy, 2002. All measurements are in μm, except for L, in mm.

sec.title: Diagnosis (emended)
sec.p: Aporcelaimidae, Aporcelaiminae. Moderately slender to slender nematodes of medium to large size (1.05-5.00) mm long. Cuticle two or three-layered, layers with similar or dissimilar refraction. Lip region offset either by an expansion or a more or less distinct constriction. Odontostyle short and robust, with aperture occupying more than half its length. Guiding ring simple, plicate. Odontophore rod-like. Pharynx enlarging gradually, basal expansion occupying ca one-half (43-60%) of total neck length; S1N1 at about middle of DN-S1N2 distance. Female genital system didelphic-amphidelphic, uterus a simple tube, only exceptionally more complex (tripartite in A. rotundicaudata), pars refringens vaginae absent, vulva a median transverse slit (V = 45-62). Tail similar in both sexes, short, hemispherical to conical, occasionally with a weak dorsal concavity. Spicules dorylaimoid. Ventromedian supplements 3-17 in number, hiatus (precloacal space) present.

sec.title: Relationships
sec.p: The emended diagnosis of Aporcella includes some novelties (variations) observed in recently described species but does not substantially modify its concept nor its separation from its closest relatives within Aporcelaimidae Heyns, 1965. Thus, it differs from Aporcelaimellus Heyns, 1965 in lacking pars refringens vaginae, an apparently minor feature that might have more evolutionary interest than previously assumed, as repeatedly shown by molecular analyses (see above). From Metaporcelaimus Lordello, 1965 it can be distinguished by tail morphology (rounded to conical with regular inner core vs invariably conical with distinctly irregular or notched inner core). Some Aporcella species, in particular those with a comparatively small size, also resemble some representatives of other genera lacking pars refringens vaginae, for instance Discolaimium Thorne, 1939 (Qudsianematidae, Discolaiminae) or Moshajia Siddiqi, 1982 (Qudsianematidae, Lordellonematinae). Molecular analyses based on both LSU (Álvarez-Ortega & Peña-Santiago, 2016; Naghavi et al., 2020; present results) and SSU (Imran et al., 2019) genes show that these taxa form a monophyletic group whose internal taxonomy needs further studies for its elucidation.

sec.title: Remarks
sec.p: Álvarez-Ortega et al. (2013) redefined the genus Aporcella on the basis of the morphological and molecular characterisation of A. simplex from the USA. One of the novelties of their emended diagnosis of the genus was the three-layered nature of its cuticle, later confirmed in other species such as A. vitrinus and A. charidemiensis, both from Spain (Álvarez-Ortega & Peña-Santiago, 2013a, 2016). Nevertheless, the three new Iranian species recently described (Naghavi et al., 2019, 2020; present contribution) display a two-layered cuticle. There is, therefore, a remarkable intrageneric variability in this character, as mentioned in the new diagnosis of the genus provided above. Unfortunately, older (and some not so old…) descriptions did not pay too much attention to this trait, which should be a matter for deeper analyses.

sec.title: Other species

Pharyngeal expansion occupying 58-63% of total neck length .................... malekimilanii

fn.p: The specific epithet is from the Latin word minor = smaller, and referring to the general size of the new species.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The Spanish author is grateful for the support received from research action ‘PAIJUA 2019/2020: EI_RNM02_2019’ of the University of Jaén, Spain, for his scientific work.
